%mbx script removed problem header For the function \[f(x) = \begin{cases} 2 x - 5, & 0\le x < 4\\ 5, & x = 4\\ x^2 - 8 x + 19, & 4 < x \end{cases}\] use algebra to find each of the following limits: \leavevmode\\\relax \(\lim\limits_{x\to 4^{+}}\, f(x) =\) \mbox{\parbox[t]{7.5ex}{\hrulefill}} \leavevmode\\\relax \(\lim\limits_{x\to 4^{-}}\, f(x) =\) \mbox{\parbox[t]{7.5ex}{\hrulefill}} \leavevmode\\\relax \(\lim\limits_{x\to 4}\, f(x) =\) \mbox{\parbox[t]{7.5ex}{\hrulefill}} \leavevmode\\\relax {\it (For each, enter {\bf DNE} if the limit does not exist.)} \par Sketch a graph of \(f(x)\) to confirm your answers.
\par \par {\bf Solution: }\par SOLUTION \par
The graph of \(f(x)\) is shown below. \par \begin{center} \includegraphics[width=0.2\linewidth]{webwork-tex/webwork-9-image-1.png}
\end{center} \par From this, and from the given formula for \(f(x)\), we can see that \leavevmode\\\relax \(\lim\limits_{x\to 4^{+}}\, f(x) = 3\), and \leavevmode\\\relax \(\lim\limits_{x\to 4^{-}}\, f(x) = 3\). \leavevmode\\\relax These are the same value, so we know that the limit must exist: \(\lim\limits_{x\to 4}\, f(x) = 3\). \par Note, however, that \(f(x)\) is not continuous at \(x=4\) since \(f(4)=5 \ne 3\).
\par
